Initial issue: intermittently not working and would hum but blades would barely turn or not at all. At the repair event, we took it apart starting with the plastic clips holding the outer "cage". We noticed it was dusty, the main rod attaching to the blades was rusted, and the blades turned but were stiff. I had oiled it at home but not taken it apart. We continued disassembly, next removing the fan blades. They took a firm and steady pull to get off the main pole. Be careful here, because the plastic can crack around where it threads onto the pole. Mine did and we had to glue it. Next, we removed the 2 nuts and washers holding the back of the "cage" onto the fan. From there, the next disassembly was to get the motor out. I wanted to check the electronics and see if anything looked bad. We removed the bolts holding the legs/base and that allowed the motor to slide out. We had to flex the plastic to get it out. there are also 2 metal tabs that the bolts screw into, acting as nuts. make sure not to lose those. Once we pulled out the motor, someone came over to help who was familiar w similar fans. He suggested we lubricate the bearings both at the front and back of the rotating pole. Everything just looked old and rusty, but nothing was super messed up. We used deoxit to lube the parts, and it made a huge difference. We also krazy glued the part of the fan blade assembly that we'd inadvertently broken during disassembly. Lastly, we scraped off some of the rust from the main pole near where the blades attach. When reassembling, make sure the base is pointing in the right direction. Make sure you screw the base bolts into the metal tabs. when reattaching the fan blades, make sure the plastic gaps line up with the little perpendicular metal stoppers that stick out from the pole. After reassembling some, we tested and saw that the fan ran quietly and well. After full reassembly, the same was true. lubing the back bearing was important for long term repair! I lubed only the front initially but it wasn't enough.

. When we arrived, a Volunteer (Tom) showed us how to use a multimeter in order to determine that yes, our lamp had a short. First we checked the cord connections to the bulb socket and re-connected them to make sure they were tight and clean. The multimeter indicated that there was still a problem, though, so we took the lamp apart and found that the entire wire needed replacing. We did this, ensuring that the ground wire and the live wire were consistently threaded throughout. We left happily with a working lamp. First, make sure you have the right tools: screwdriver, wire strippers/cutters, a replacement wire that is the right length and meant to carry the same voltage, and a multimeter, at bare minimum. Our lamp was a floor lamp with a tall, skinny post that the cable went through. I wished I'd had a long, narrow stick that I could poke into that post. Next, take a good look at your lamp and think about how it might come apart. Look for screws, caps, or other joined places that will provide access to the wire inside the lamp. Think about what might be necessary in order to get the wire out (and in). Visualizing the process before you start is a good idea. There's probably a lot of reference on how to go about fixing the wiring on a lamp online, but it was very helpful to have someone guide us through the process. I never would have thought to use a multimeter, but using it as a way of testing our work instead of just plugging the lamp in was a good thing, it avoided potentially shorting the circuit at the event.

. The microwave turntable wasn't turning, so I had purchased a replacement motor over a year ago and brought it with me to the event. We replaced the motor and now the turntable turns. Yay! Changing the motor was easy, but getting the case/housing off the microwave was challenging. On the bottom of the microwave, there was a covering right over the motor, but we didn't think we could open it since it required cutting metal to do so. To get the case off, we needed a special tool (Security Torx screwdriver, which is a 6-sided star-shaped screwdriver with a pin in it) and luckily (amazingly), someone at the Fixit Clinic had one. We also used a regular Phillips screwdriver. We kept liberating parts of the case and finding that we had to unscrew more screws to get to the area we needed. (Also, it's a bit intimidating working with electric wires and stuff but we just avoided touching those.) After a lot of work, we got the whole case off of the microwave, but none of that was necessary after all. EXCEPT, by opening the case, we found some super secret instructions taped onto the microwave underneath the case, so it DID tell us what to do! It turned out we COULD get in through the covering right over the motor (so we only needed to open that, not take the entire case off). It turned out, you do just cut the metal, open it up, replace the motor, and then rotate the cover 180 degrees and it has tabs that slip into slots so it can be reused after being cut. The motor itself just needed to be unplugged, rotated, and pulled out. Then we plugged in the new one and rotated it into place. Voila! .

My coffee maker was successfully repaired at the 2/8/25 Boston Building Resources Fixit clinic! The issue with the coffee maker was that the water did not pump. The grinder function and the display still worked, but no water flowed through the system. We took the coffee maker apart to look for the pump. After taking it all the way apart, we realized that there was no pump and the coffee maker used heat alone to push water through the tubing. The issue was that a thermal fuse had blown, and so the circuit for the heating element was broken. A fixer helped me test the connectivity of the fuse and soldered a new wire to bypass the broken fuse (the coffee maker had a second, redundant thermal fuse that had not blown). After this repair step, the coffee maker worked! I have made my coffee with it every morning since. Check the connectivity of the various electrical components first. This was something we could have done very early in the process, and if we had then we would have avoided the cumbersome process of taking the coffee maker apart.

Replacing the lock is relatively easy and requires a screwdriver and a pair of pliers. Follow this video https://youtu.be/C2k3w6suShU?t=196 to see how to remove the silicone seal. . The waffle iron (my mother's, dating to the 1940s) was disassembled and tested. Preliminarily, since no substitute cords were available, we reinserted the old line into the machine connector. I had already intended to purchase a new cord. The specific electrical requirements of the machine were explained to me, so now I know how to buy the correct cord. We unscrewed the bottom plate, exposing the workings of the lower griddle. When tested, the electrical circuit was fine. The control governing the degree of doneness of the waffle is a completely mechanical thing, running from the knob outside to two little flanges in the middle of the machine which expand or contract with heat. They seemed to be a little stuck (which may account for complaints about overheating). I was advised to sand them down with 600-1200 grit sandpaper to clear the accumulation. I had a lot of questions about cleaning, water, etc. which were answered. So far so good. When we unscrewed the top to expose the upper waffle iron, however, the electrical circuit did not complete. The little white wires leading from the plug to the hot plate part were defective. Diagnosis: the white wires of both top and bottom valves need to be replaced, along with their receptor nuts and bolts; and the heat gauge flanges need to be sanded. It should take an electrical repairman about an hour to do. The going rate for electrical repair in Berkeley is $50-75/ hour. As instructed, I will phone Al Lasher's Electronics on University Avenue for a recommendation. The decision to restore a vintage electrical appliance is based on many factors. The initial assessment at the clinic establishes an upper limit of feasibility and cost. Beyond that, more personal considerations-- environmental, aesthetic and sentimental-- must be taken into account. How much do I loathe sending things to landfill (or having them sent to landfill by whoever inherits the non functional waffle iron)? A lot. Would a second-hand replacement (say from the Oakland Museum White Elephant Sale) be any safer than an appliance (ungrounded, to be sure) which I had had rewired? No. Do I even need a waffle iron? I've lived thirty years with this one in storage. But so many interesting new whole grain waffle recipes are circulating. Could I find a second-hand stove-top iron? As I see it right now, this is a perfectly good waffle iron which can be fixed with a trivial amount of work. Since I lack the skills to fix it myself I have to pay someone to do it. For people retired on a small fixed income in Berkeley everything is ridiculously expensive. I have suggested several times to the North Berkeley Senior Center that it would be good to maintain a list of retired repairmen who would be willing to undertake occasional work for less than the going rate. I have even suggested a program of exchanged work or skills. I can cook or garden expertly in exchange for a small electrical repair. In vain. The unimaginative management is totally uninterested in improving the lives of its members.

. Oven intermittently would not heat and turntable wouldn't turn. At repair event the probable issue was determined to be a series of switches that are engaged by the door. Went ahead and ordered a latch hook, PHOK-A137WRFZ, two switches QSW-MA131WRE0 and a switch/fuse combination FFS-BA021WRK0. I removed the latch hook assembly and tested the three switches. They seemed fine. Installed the new latch hook with the new switches, but noticed that this assembly is designed to be adjustable and has "play" while the two screws that hold it aren't tightened. With the door closed, this assembly can be accurately aligned to optimally engage the switches. I did this and then tightened the two screws holding it with the hope they would not move over many years. The system works now without any intermittent failures. When the oven was in a state where it wouldn't start, it could reliably be started after going through one or more cycles of pushing the "open" mechanical button on the front while holding the door closed. This process is referred to in the service manual as helpful in aligning the latch hook. It also exercises the process of engaging the 3 switches on the latch hook and might guide people to this resolution.
